column8: Many people experience homelessness in a variety of ways– sometimes in a tent, other times in the home of a friend or family member.
column11: In Sacramento, as in most cities, there are not enough emergency shelter beds for every person that is homeless on any given night.
column14: In the past, most bouts of homelessness did not extend past a week up to a several months, but this situation may be changing due to Sacramento County’s budget problems.
column17: If you find yourself homeless without previous preparation, this section will help you until you are able to access shelter or housing.
column20: Remember that many that find themselves homeless might not be so different from yourself, so there is a great resource by peer support and advice.
column23: A great starting point would be a service provider like Loaves & Fishes.
column235: Keeping Safe When You’re If You’re Staying Outside Homeless
column238: Keep from freezing – cardboard is a great insulator from the cold ground and provides some cushion when sleeping on cement.
column241: If you don’t have a tent, a tarp is a must for camping gear, and a warm sleeping bag.
column244: Sometimes sleeping bags are available at Loaves & Fishes’ Friendship Park at 1 PM by the service center.
column247: You may also be able to obtain coats and rain gear.
column250: Friendship Park also provides activities, information, restroom facilities and a safe environment while you access services.
column253: The center is located at 1321 North C Street.
column256: Staying dry – If you have a tent, make sure it has a rain fly or secure one tarp over the tent and one under the tent.
column259: If you do not have a tent, a tarp is very important when living outdoors.
column262: Finding a place to sleep under cover is sometimes hard to find, but many sleep communally under freeways dur- ing rain storms.
column265: Sleeping in doorways of businesses that have gone out of business is a good place to sleep out of the rain.
column268: You can use trash bags for raincoats by cutting out holes for your head and arms.
column274: Safe Ground Sacramento is a good resource if you must sleep outdoors and would like to camp amongst others in a drug, alcohol and violence free environment.
column277: Safe Ground Sacramento are organizing to acquire land and simple cottages, but meanwhile members just camp together and support each other, sometimes being hosted by a church to sleep indoors on some cold nights.
column280: Often they can provide camping equip- ment and other supplies when you stay with them.
column283: Office is located in Loaves & Fishes Friendship Park at 1321 North C Street.
column289: Keeping cool – keep wet towel or something wet around neck or over head.
column292: Drink lots of water to stay hydrated.
column295: Avoid alcohol drinks because they dehydrate.
column298: Wildlife – Skunks, raccoons, possums, and rats are some of the wildlife you may come upon.
column301: Even the skunks don’t usually present too much of a danger, but they can be pests.
column304: Just don’t keep food lying around and tie your food in bags from strings or rope from tree branches.
column307: Snakes – rattle snakes are rare but can be dangerous .There are more rattle snake sightings upriver from Busi- ness 80 along the American River Parkway.
column310: Stinging nettles are native to Sacramento area and if you touch them with your skin it will burn immensely for awhile.
column313: Poison oak – Don’t burn by mistake because the smoke can cause serious reactions.
column316: Mosquitoes – Minimize exposure of your skin during late afternoon and evening hours by wearing long sleeves.
column333: Fires – It’s best not to have campfires, especially along the parkway.
column336: An alternative is to purchase a propane heater and/ or camp stove for keeping warm and for cooking.
column339: If you sleep in a tent, a simple candle in an open jar will provide heat for the small space inside a tent and the jar will help prevent lit candles from falling over and causing fires.
column342: If you have no alternative and must have a fire to keep warm, dig a small pit and make sure there are no tree roots exposed to the pit.
column345: If you need a fire to cook, use a small fire using only several twigs at a time, instead of a log.
column348: There is too much danger of fires in the summer.
column351: Protection from predators – Use your valuables as a pillow, by sleeping with your backpack or purse under your head, or wrap a strap around your arms.
column354: If you sleep in a hidden location, make sure that no stranger sees you enter or leave your camp.
column360: Healthy feet “Happy Feet” – Sweater sleeves can be cut off to make socks.
column363: After you cut the sleeve off, use the cut part for your feet, folding the edges so they fit around your feet flat and comfortably.
column366: You can also keep a plastic bag over your foot.
column369: Try to keep dry between toes.
column372: Use a petroleum base jelly on your feet to deal with soreness and dryness.
column375: Restroom facilities – Finding facilities open to the public are often hard to find.
column378: More and more restaurants are not allowing people to use their restrooms without making a pur- chase.
column381: Public and government buildings such as libraries, post offices, county administration, city hall and others are good places to go.
column384: In some buildings you will have to ask security for access.
column387: Homeless and other services agencies usually have restrooms.
column390: Restrooms at public parks are somewhat scarce and are usually closed from early evening to morning.
column393: If no restrooms are available, urinate on dirt or vegetation, never on impermeable surfaces.
column396: Camp etiquette and types of locations to sleep – Some- times you will see a bedroll and other belongings that appear to be abandoned.
column402: The owner will probably come back for them that same night or even next week.
column408: That way you perpetuate the custom so that you may feel better about leaving your possessions somewhere when you have an appointment or other reason.
column411: Don’t assume your possessions will be there when you return, though, since not everyone follows that custom and sometimes the police or rangers take things (they are required to give a notice before they take your things and leave a notice where you can pick your things up, but they don’t always follow this procedure).
column414: Dumpster Diving – It can be dangerous and it is illegal to go through residential garbage cans.
column417: Some businesses put useful items outside their dumpters.
column420: You can find many use- ful items in dumpsters and with a good stick with a hook on the end, you can safely scavenge without having to enter the dumpster.
column423: Behind laundramats may be good for blankets and clothing.
column426: If someone else is searching a dumpster, let them finish before you start.
column429: Be careful with food by checking ex- piration dates, freshness and ability to decontaminate (such as vegetables and fruits without cuts).
column457: Emergency Shelters Your Rights As A Homeless Camper
column460: Both City and County Ordinances make it a misdemeanor offense to camp on public property, including the American River Parkway.
column463: Persons found camping in Sacramento can be given a citation, which requires appearance in court and/ or payment of a fine.
column466: You have a right to a jury trial if the citation is a misdemeanor and a right to only a court trial if you are cited for an infraction.
column469: If you are cited for a mis- demeanor, you are entitled to be represented by a public defender.
column472: It is unlikely, if you plead “not guilty” and request appointment of a public defender, that they will take your case to trial.
column475: Before your camping and personal property may be re- moved, you are entitled to receive a “48 hour notice” which will tell you to remove your property or it will be confiscated and stored.
column478: If it is not removed within 48 hours, it can be seized and stored, but a second notice must be given telling you where the property has been taken and how it can be reclaimed.
column481: If your property is taken and stored without the required notice in County jurisdiction, you have a claim for violation of a settlement agreement.
column484: If your property is taken and de- stroyed, you have the right to file a federal or state complaint for damages for seizure of property without due process.
column487: Sacramento City Code 12.52.030 Unlawful camping – this ordinance, also, makes it against the law to camp on private property for longer than 24 hours, and to “store” camping equipment on public property (which could mean setting your camping gear on the ground).

column235: Where Can I Get Low Cost Housing?
column238: Most low-income households are eligible for government housing that will cost at least 30% of their income for rent, but the waiting lists are very long.
column241: Public Housing is housing owned and operated by the housing authority.
column244: In Sacramento that is the Sacramento Housing and Redevelopment Agency.
column247: There is a long waiting list for public housing in Sacramento.
column250: Most of the time, the waiting list is closed.
column253: Watch for announcements when the public housing waiting list is open.
column256: Some of these projects advertise their availability and you can apply directly at the building or at a leasing office.
column259: Most of the time, the best way to get into this kind of housing is to go through special programs offered by community agen- cies that will help you get into housing when you finish the program.
column262: The programs prioritize housing for people who: • have a disability, including mental illness and/or HIV/AIDS • have a substance abuse problem and want to get treat- ment for it • have children under 18 with them • are over 60 years old • are a veteran There is not very much Project Based housing available now, and there are waiting lists at most buildings.
column265: It may take you months or longer to get housing you need, but it is worth the try.
column333: Housing Choice (formerly called Section 8) vouchers are offered by the local government (the Housing Authority).
column336: They allow you to stay in any apartment or house where the landlord will accept them, and you pay a limited amount of money you can afford for rent (usually 30% of your income).
column339: Housing Choice voucher recipients are also protected by rent control and state laws.
column342: An owner also has to give you at least 90 days notice if they want to stop accepting section 8 vouchers.
column345: If your unit is protected by rent control, the owner must also comply with those requirements.
column348: When you receive a Housing Choice voucher you will have 60 days to find a landlord who will accept it, or you will have to return the voucher.
column351: At this time not many landlords are accepting the vouchers.
column354: There is a long waiting list for housing choice vouchers in Sacramento.
column357: Most of the time, the waiting list is closed.
column360: Watch for an- nouncements when the housing choice voucher waiting list is open.Housing Choice vouchers can be terminated by the housing authority if you do not comply with the many program requirements.
column363: If the housing authority gives you a notice that it is terminating your voucher, you can appeal.
column366: You can also appeal if you disagree with the amount of your voucher of if you are denied a voucher.
column369: Look on any notices you have for how to ask for a grievance and for how long you have to ask for a grievance.
column372: You can contact Legal Services of Northern California for help.

column1011: If your landlord does not fix the problems and you live in the County of Sacra- mento, call Code Enforcement at (916) 874-6444.
column1014: In the City of Sacramento call (916) 264-5011 or 3-1-1.

column1023:
You have the right to live in a place that has no holes in the wall, has working toilets, sinks, electricity, heat, no rats, roaches or other pests,
 and is clean.
column1026: The landlord has to fix things that don’t work that you did not break.
column1029: If you live in the City of Sacramento and you are told you must move by Code Enforcement (your unit is “red tagged”) you may be eligible for relocation assistance from the City which will be two times your monthly rent plus the amount of your prior security deposit.
column1038: If your landlord will not fix problems, you should give written notice of the problem (remember to keep copies of everything relating to the problem), wait 30 days, and have proof of the problem.
column1041: If you want to repair the problem yourself and deduct the cost from your rent, it must be a problem affecting your health or safety, not just something you want to change in the apartment.

column238: The Women, Infants and Children program, called WIC, pro- vides vouchers for certain foods and nutrition education for pregnant women, women who just had a baby, breastfeeding women , and children up to age 5 (including foster children and children raised by their father as well as other children).
column241: You qualify for WIC if your household receives Food Stamps, CalWORKs or full Medi-Cal.

column256: It is helpful, but not requi ¿ red, to bring current medical information when you apply.
column259: If you are treated unfairly in any way, you can complain to the supervisor at the WIC site or hand in a short note or let- ter requesting a hearing.

column235: Can My Child Get Free School Breakfast and Lunch?
column238: All low-income children qualify for free or reduced price school meals, regardless of immigration status.
column241: Children who eat regular meals learn better and are usually sick less than other children.
column244: All public schools and some private and paro- chial schools offer breakfast and lunch programs.
column247: Your child qualifies for free or reduced-price meals if your gross family income per month (income before taxes or deductions) is below a certain level.
column250: You should be given an application for the meal program in your own language at the beginning of the school year or whenever your child transfers.
column253: You can also ask for one at any time from the school office, because if your income goes down during the year, your child may become eligible.
column256: If you receive CalWORKs, food stamps, or the Food Distribu- tion Program on Indian Reservations, the only information you have to give is your case number, and your child automatically qualifies for free meals.
column259: If you do not receive CalWORKs or food stamps, you will have to list the total income of your household, the names of household members, and the Social Security number of the adult signing the application.
column262: If you do not have a number, just write “none”.
column265: You are not required to apply for a number or give a reason for not having one.
column268: In some cases, you must give the school some proof of your income (by showing your pay stubs to the school secretary, for example).
column271: All information gathered is confidential and cannot be given to other government agencies.
column274: If the information you give on the application shows that you qualify, your child can begin receiving free or reduced-price meals immediately.
column277: Foster children are often eligible for free meals, regardless of the foster parents’ income.
column280: Extra Food for Pregnant Students At many schools, pregnant and breastfeeding students can get extra food at breakfast or lunch, or an extra snack.
column283: To be eligible, the student must provide some written verification that she is pregnant or breastfeeding from a doctor, nurse, midwife, clinic, WIC or Cal-Learn program.
column333: A ll children age 18 and under regardless of income can eat free, nutritious meals during the summer or any time when school is out for more than 15 days through the Summer Meals Program.
column336: If the child is physically disabled, the age limit is 21.
column339: No application or other kind of paperwork is required.
column342:
Meals
 and snacks are served at schools, parks, community centers and recreation centers.
column345: To find out where your children can eat free when they are not in school, call the City of Sacarmento at (916) 498-1000 or the CA Department of Education for summer meal sites: 800-952-5609.
column348: If you want to learn how to start free Summer Lunch in your area, call the California Food Policy Advocates at (213) 482-8200.
column460: • The law says that children who get free or reduced-price meals cannot be treated differently than those who get full- price meals.
column463: No separate lines, different meals or meal tickets, required work, or other types of discrimination are allowed.
column466: • Ask the school, child-care sponsor, or summer recreation program sponsor for a “fair hearing” if you apply and are unfairly denied.
column469: Also request the hearing if you receive notice that your benefits will be cut.
column472: By doing so within 10 days, your child’s benefits will continue until the hearing takes place.

column8: In March 2010, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) was signed into law.
column11: The goal of health reform is make sure that more Americans have insurance, either public or private.
column14: Medi-Cal, a state-subsidized healthcare, will expand to cover higher incomes.
column17: More information about Medi-Cal, eligibility and the application process is below.
column20: Starting in January 2014, if you do not qualify for Medi-Cal or another public health care program, you will be required to have another means of health insurance.
column23: Even if you do not qualify for Medi-Cal, you may be eligible for the Pre- mium Assistance Program.
column26: This can help to reduce the cost of your health insurance premium, which is the amount of money you pay to buy health insurance coverage each month.
column29: Depending on your income, Cost Sharing Assistance can reduce the amount of health care expenses an individ- ual has to pay when getting care.
column32: These expenses include copayments and other health care bills.
column35: Covered California’s Health Benefit Exchange marketplace can help you find affordable health plans and answer any questions you may have.
column41: To calculate an estimatead cost of health- care, visit www.coveredca.com/calculating_the_cost.html.
column44: You may also contact Sacramento Covered at 1-866-850- 4321 for assistance in finding a health plan.
column47: Starting January 1, 2014, you cannot be denied coverage because of a pre-existing condition (this has already begun for children under age 19).
column50: If you are a young adult under age 26, you can remain on your parents’ private health coverage.
column56: For more information on changes to private health insurance, visit www.coveredca.com.
column238: Medi-Cal is a health insurance program to help pay the medi- cal expenses of low income families, seniors, and people with disabilities.
column241: The state and federal government fund Medi-Cal.
column244: There are many Medi-Cal programs with different rules.
column247: Depending on which program you qualify for and how much money you make, Medi-Cal may pay for all your medical expenses or you might have to pay a share of the cost when you access health care services in a particular month.
column253: Groups of Eligibility You can get Medi-Cal if you: • Meet income and resource tests and • Are a California resident and intend to stay in California and •Fit within one of the eligible groups.
column256: The major groups who can get Medi-Cal are: • People getting SSI, CalWORKs, foster care, adoption assistance, or certain immigrants receiving Entrant or Refugee Cash Assistance benefits.
column259: These groups get free Medi-Cal with no “Share of Cost.” • Pregnant women • Children under age 21 • Adults 65 or over • People of any age who are disabled or blind by SSI guide- lines (whether or not you are getting SSI) • Families in which at least one parent is absent, deceased, disabled or unable to work, unemployed, or under-em- ployed.
column262: “Unemployed” means that the parent who has earned the most in the past two years is working less than 100 hours a month.
column265: “Underemployed” means that the fam- ily’s earned income is below the federal poverty level.
column268: • Taking care of a related child under 21 • Refugees • People living in a long term care facility • People recieving dialysis for kidney failure • People infected with tuberculosis (unless undocumented) • Women (and some men) diagnosed with breast or cervi- cal cancer.
column271: Besides fitting into one of the above categories, you must also meet certain income and resource limits.
column274: If your children are low income but get too much income to qualify for Medi-Cal, en 2.
column277: Immigration Status If you are a California resident and meet other Medi-Cal re- quirements, you can apply for a restricted Medi-Cal card, even if you’re undocumented.
column280: This will pay for emergency services, pregnancy-related care and long term care services.
column283: Most low income legal immigrants can get regular (also called full-scope) Medi-Cal to cover most of their medically neces- sary health needs.
column286: Many immigrants can get full health coverage, even if they do not have a green card, for example those who are victims of domestic violence, or those in the process of adjusting their legal status (i.e., they are applying for Legal Permanent Residency).
column289: If you are receiving CalWORKs, SSI, foster care, or certain refugee benefits, you get Medi-Cal automatically and do not need to apply separately.
column330: How Do I Apply for Medi-Cal?
column336: Get an Application Form You can get one mailed to you by calling the DHA toll-free number at 1 (888) 747-1222; or you can get one at a DHA Office.
column339: (See page 69); or you can get one at many hospitals and clinics, whether they are private or county-run.
column345: Children Under Age 19 You may apply for Medi-Cal for your children.
column348: Children who receive a CHDP visit are screened for temporary eligibility for Medi-Cal.
column351: If a child is eligible, he/she is pre-enrolled in temporary, full-scope Medi-Cal at no cost for up to 60 days (for the month of the visit and the month after).
column354: Infants who were born to a woman recieving Medi-Cal at the time of birth should receive Medi-Cal ongoing until the age of one.
column360: Filling Out the Application You can get help filling out the application by calling (916) 874-3100.
column363: A Medi-Cal worker will go over the application you filled out.
column366: If you are asked for more information, you will be given a list of what is needed and a specific date by which the information must be mailed to the Medi-Cal office.
column375: Provide Needed Papers • Identification with your name and current address on it.
column378: For example, a birth certificate, driver’s license, or California ID card.
column381: If you lack ID, you can fill out a form called “PA 853” and swear that you are who you say you are , or documents to verify income or disability status may also serve as proof of identity.
column384: • Social Security Number or Card (or proof of application for the card) only for those requesting "full-scope" benefits.
column387: • Proof of income (like check stubs,a copy of your tax return, a self-affidavit or statement of income if you are paid in cash or do not have any other way to prove income) • Proof that you live in Sacramento County (a document that has your name and an address on it, such as an ID, a bill mailed to your house, school attendance records, pay stubs, etc.)
column390: for each adult on the application.
column393: • Proof of U.S. citizenship and identity or acceptable immi- gration status for each person on the application who has declared acceptable immigration status.
column396: If you are a parent applying for children only, you do not need to submit proof of your immigration status.
column399: • Vehicle registration if ownership of more than one vehicle is declared.
column402: • Verification of child or dependent care, educational expenses and/or health insurance premiums or court ordered child sup- port payments can be used as deductions, but are not needed to determine eligibility.
column408: Cooperate With Child Support Services If one parent is absent, most people will have to cooperate with DHA and a county agency called the Department of Child Support Services (DCSS.)
column411: You must provide information you have about the other parent such as an address or social security number, to establish who your child’s absent father or mother is and whether that parent can provide the child with medical insurance.
column417: Wait for Approval Normally, the Medi-Cal office will approve or deny your ap- plication within 45 days of receiving it, except for the faster ways for children, described above.
column420: If the state must evaluate a disability, the approval or denial can be delayed up to 90 days.
column423: If Medi-Cal denies your benefits, you can appeal.
column460: Your countable income determines whether or not you can get Medi-Cal for free or whether you have to pay a “Share of Cost.” (You only pay a "share of cost" in months when you actually use services.)
column463: Certain types of income don’t count or can be subtracted.
column466: The different Medi-Cal programs count the income limits differently.
column469: It’s important when applying for Medi-Cal to report income and expenses including: • Up to $175 (this may be subject to change) for child care for each child age 2 and over • $200 (this may be subject to change) for childcare for each child under age two • Court-ordered child and spousal support paid • Child support received • Educational expenses • Business expenses of self-employed parents.
column472: Once a family qualifies for Medi-Cal, hundreds of dollars of their earnings might not count against their eligibility.
column475: Elderly (65 and older), blind or disabled persons can deduct (these amounts may be subject to change): • $20 • $65 from earned income • Half of any remaining earned income • Any health insurance premiums paid by you.
column478:
Some elderly or disabled people, even though not receiving
 SSI, may get free Medi-Cal if the countable monthly income is less than a certain amount.
column481: This is called the “Aged and Disabled Federal Poverty Level” Medi-Cal program.
column484: If you are over these limits you can still get Medi-Cal, but there will be a share of cost.
column487: Special Low-Cost Medi-Cal for Working Disabled Persons: If you are a disabled working person or are married and both of you are working and disabled, you can get lower cost Medi-Cal if your income if you meet the income requirements.
column490: If you qualify, you will have to pay a monthly premium that goes up the more income that you have.
column512: The resource limit does not apply to pregnant women for care related to their pregnancy, or to children under 19 in certain Medi-Cal programs.
column515: For anyone else, your family’s resources must be below certain limits to get Medi-Cal: Some assets do not count.
column518: The home you live in, furnishings, personal items, and some non-term life insurance policies don’t count.
column533: 1. Who Pays Share of Cost Some people must pay, or agree to pay, a “Share of Cost” for each month that they have a medical expense.
column536: Medi-Cal will then pay the rest of the bill for covered services that month.
column539: You do NOT have to pay a Share of Cost if: • You are in one of the groups that receive free Medi-Cal (such as those getting CalWORKs, SSI, foster care, adoption assis- tance, 1931(b) Medi-Cal, or the aged and disabled programs).
column542: • Your countable income is below certain income limits.
column545: If you have Medi-Cal with a Share of Cost, you begin each month with your Share of Cost limit.
column548: You don’t have to pay anything in months that you have no medical expense.
column551: You can use past medical bills and the medical bills of family members listed on your application to meet your Share of Cost, including unpaid bills that they are trying to collect from you.
column554: You cannot count the same billed item or service twice, but you can carry the balance of an unpaid bill over to later months if a bill is for more than your Share of Cost.
column557: If your income goes down, notify your worker so your “Share of Cost” will go down.
column575: Once a Year Eligibility Form Individuals receiving Medi-Cal must have their eligibility rechecked (or “redetermined”) every 12 months.
column578: You get a "redetermination packet" in the mail which you must fill out and send back.
column581: You do not have to send in copies of docu- ments with your redetermination form.
column592: Mid-Year Status Report For Adults Some adults recieving Medi-Cal must fill out the Mid-Year Status Report (MSR) in order to keep Medi-Cal.
column595: Some groups of people do not have to fill our the MSR: a child under 21; the parent or guardian of a CalWORKS child; pregnant women who have reported their pregnancy to the county, people who are disabled or over 65, or someone in the Breast or Cervical Cancer Program.
column621: There are two ways to receive your medical care under Medi- Cal in Sacramento County: ”Fee for service” (regular Medi-Cal), or Geographic Managed Care (GMC) which gives services through private health plans.
column624: Medi-Cal participants except for people on SSI and people in long term care must use GMC.
column630: Fee for Service (Regular Medi-Cal) In Fee for Service Medi-Cal you can use any doctor, clinic, hospital, pharmacy or other provider willing to accept Medi- Cal.
column633: You must tell the doctor or clinic that you have Medi-Cal before you get care.
column636: If you don’t, the provider can legally bill you for all services that you get.
column653: If you are between 12 and 21 years old and a citizen or legal resident, you can apply for “Minor Consent Services” to get free and confidential medical treatment without parental consent related to: • Drug or alcohol abuse treatment or counseling (except methadone treatment) • Sexually transmitted diseases • Pregnancy and abortion • Family planning • Outpatient mental health (not overnight in a hospital) • Sexual abuse Your parents won’t be required to give information about their income or resources or pay toward the medical services, unless you want Medi-Cal for services other than those listed above.
column656: DHA won’t tell your parents or send Medi-Cal mailings to your home without your permission.
column659: These services can be used by minors even if they already have Medi-Cal or any other health program.
column662: To apply, fill out the regular Medi-Cal application and another short form for Minor Consent Services at DHA or with a DHA Eligibility Worker at the site where you are receiving care.
column665: You will have to fill out a new short form each month you need treatment, except for mental health services.
column1285: Income deductions and exemptions apply, so apply even if you think your income may be too high; you can contact Legal Services of Northern California at (916) 551-2150 if you are denied.
column1395: Other real estate may not count if you are not the only owner or are not able to sell it.
column1398: For some Medi-Cal programs one car does not count, and for some programs a car is not counted if its value is under a specific amount.
column2080: The Medi-Cal Card Once you have been “approved,” you may ask your worker for a written verification of your eligibility status from the Medi- Cal Eligibility Data Systems (MEDS) or your medical provider may be able to use your Social Security Number to verify your eligibility status through their Point of Service system.
column2083: Your permanent white plastic Medi-Cal card, called a “Benefit Identification Card” or BIC, is mailed to your address.
column2086: Each person listed on your application will get one, even if they aren’t eligible for Medi-Cal, because if the family must pay a monthly Share of Cost, the medical expenses of every per- son listed on the application can be used to meet the Share of Cost.
column2089: If you don’t get your plastic card by the end of the month, or lose it, contact your worker.

column2101: Authorization For Service Under Fee-for-Service Before certain medical services can be performed for you the state or your health plan has to give an authorization for the service.

column2113: However, if the state or health plan denies or changes the authorization, the state will notify you and your doctor.
column2116: You can appeal any unreasonable delay, denial, reduction, or termination of care.
column2125: If You Are Pregnant If you are not more than 30 weeks pregnant and have too much income to be eligible for free Medi-Cal, you may be eligible for a program called AIM (Access for Infants and Mothers).
column2131: You can also get AIM even if you have medical insurance, if your insurance does not cover pregnancy or if you have a $500 "deductible".
column2134: Many pregnant woman can get a temporary Medi-Cal card called "Presumptive Eligibility" immediately, without show- ing proof of pregnancy or providing information on property, car, or resources.
column2137: This will help you get early prenatal care, lab tests and medication.
column2140: You still have to turn in a regular Medi-Cal application and provide proof of income by the end of the next month if you still need Medi-Cal.

You are automatically eligible for Medicare Part A free of charge if you are one of the following: • You are 65 or older and are eligible for Social Secu- rity retiree benefits based on your own or your spouse’s employment • You are a federal employee who retired after 1982 and have enough quarters of coverage • You have been receiving Social Security Disability In- come payments for 24 consecutive months • You are age 50 or older and are a disabled widow or widower who has received Social Security through your spouse for at least 2 years • You have end-stage kidney disease, or you have Lou Gehrig's disease (in either case, you still must have worked enough quarters, however, even though you don’t need to be 65)
 People who are not automatically eligible for Medicare Part A may enroll voluntarily if you meet all of the following three requirements: • You are 65 or older and • You are a U.S. citizen, or a legal alien who has resided in the U.S. continuously for at least five years and • You purchase both Parts A and B of Medicare, or you purchase Part B only.

column339: Wage Claims: You can file a wage claim with the Labor Com- missioner for any amount (or in Small Claims Court for up to $7,500) if your employer does any of the following: • Pays less than the current minimum wage.

column235: What Benefits Are Available To Immigrants?
column238: Immigrants can get many kinds of help from the government even if they don’t have a “green card.” For help with other immigration and citizenship issues see the list of agencies at the end of the chapter on pg.
column247: Benefits Available To All Immigrants All immigrants, including those without documents, can qualify for the following kinds of help: Health Care: Prenatal Care; Emergency Medi-Cal; Minor Consent Medi-Cal; Regional Centers; California Children’s Service; CHDP and Immunizations for kids.
column250: Food Programs: WIC; School Breakfast & Lunch; Help from food pantries.
column253: Other Help: Help from Shelters; Public Education; and ser- vices from many non-profit agencies.
column256: These programs don’t have immigration requirements and if you are undocumented, you may qualify.
column259: You do not need to tell anyone that you or anyone else who lives with you are undocumented.
column262: Your workers do not need to ask about your immigration status if you are not getting benefits for yourself.
column265: If they do ask you, simply tell them that you are a “not qualified” immigrant (“not qualified” is not the same as undocumented).
column268: That is all they need to know.
column271: If a school or child care center asks for your social security number on a form, you can write “none” on the form or leave it blank.
column274: They may not give the information on that form to a government agency.
column280: Victims of Trafficking, Domestic Violence, and Other Serious Crimes California law provides eligible non-citizens who are victims of trafficking, domestic violence and other serious crimes access to benefits equal to those available for refugees.
column283: • Victims of trafficking may qualify before they are certified by the federal government as victims.
column286: • Victims of domestic violence and other serious crimes may qualify once they have applied for a U visa/interim relief.
column289: • You do not need a social security number to apply.
column295: Benefits Available To Lawfully Present Immigrants Most lawfully present immigrants, such as legal permanent residents, refugees, asylees, and persons granted withholding of deportation, can get CalFresh (food assistance) benefits, CalWORKS, General Assistance, County healthcare, Housing Assistance, and Medi-Cal.
column298: If they have a sponsor, the spon- sor’s income may count as part of their income for five years.
column301: Refugees who have been in the country less than 8 months and persons who were granted asylum less than 8 months before, can also be eligible for Refugee Cash Assistance (generally this is for able bodied adults without children.
column304: Victims of trafficking may also qualify for Refugee Cash As- sistance once they receive certification.
column307: Call the local DHA office listed on page 68.

column351: Can Using Benefits Affect My Immigration Status?
column360: If you are applying to become a lawful permanent resident (green card holder) and you are using health care programs (such as Medi-Cal , In Home Supportive Services, or Healthy Families) or CalFresh, it will not hurt your chances of getting your green card by making you a "public charge".
column363: You might have a problem getting your green card if you have used cash welfare or long-term care (like a nursing home) depending on your situation.
column366: Cash aid for your children or other family members will not effect your immigration status unless it is your family’s only income.
column369: Officials will look at many factors, including your age, your health, your entire family’s (or sponsor’s) income and resources to determine whether in the future you will be likely to need to rely on cash welfare to live.
column372: Past use of cash benefits may not count against you, for example if it was several years ago that you received the benefits or if it was only for a short period of time.
column375: You do not have to worry about public charge if you already have a green card (unless you leave the US for more than 6 months at a time and try to re-enter), or if you are applying for citizenship, are a refugee or asylee, or are applying for a green card based on having lived in the US since before 1972.
column378: Victims of domestic violence who file a self-petition under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) are subject to the "public charge" test.
column381: However, they can use all benefits, including cash welfare, without affecting this decision.
column384: The government should not demand that you repay any wel- fare you correctly received as a condition of giving you legal status.
column387: If this happens, call one of the immigrant advocate agencies.
column393: Sponsors Most new immigrants entering into the U.S. through family members are required to have a sponsor sign an “affidavit of support” form.
column396: This form is a promise to the government that the sponsor will help to provide economic support for any sponsored immigrants.
column399: If you are a sponsored immigrant and you want to apply for certain government benefits, your sponsor’s income and resources may be added to yours in determining your eligibil- ity for benefits (this is called “deeming”).
column402: This deeming rule makes the income of many immigrants too high to qualify for benefits.
column405: There is no deeming if you are applying for health care programs, only for CalFresh and cash assistance programs.
column408: Deeming does not apply to some immigrants, including: refugees, asylees, parolees, victims of domestic violence who have filed a “self-petition” for an immigrant visa, or certain other immigrants who are not required to have a sponsor.

column162: 2014-2015 / SACRAMENTO COUNTY People’s Guide to HEALTH, WELFARE AND OTHER SERVICES ABOUT THE GUIDE The People’s Guide is not a directory, but a self- advocacy tool to give homeless and low-income people an active role in making a difference in their own lives.
column2640: The emphasis of the Guide is improving the information for homeless and low-income people to better access health care, housing, food, income, legal advice and employment from local, state and federal programs and community services in Sacramento County.
column2643: HOMELESSNESS, POVERTY AND HUNGER IN SACRAMENTO COUNTY • Poverty: In 2011, the amount of people living in poverty in Sacramento County was 17.7%--higher than the state average of 16.6% and the national rate of 15.9%.
